wget
http://www.cs.ucla.edu/classes/spring13/cs35L/assign/sthttpd-2.26.4.tar.gz
tar xvf sthttpd-2.26.4.tar.gz 
download and extract the sthttpd tar

cd sthttpd-2.26.4

patch -p1
patch the source by copy/pasting the patch into stdin.

./configure
emacs src/Makefile
make
generate the makefile for sthttpd, modify the makefile with
-fno-stack-protector, and compile sources.

./thttpd -p 12319
run thttpd on port 12319

wget lnxsrv.seas.ucla.edu:
command to crash the server

./thttpd -p 12319
ps -aux | grep 'thttpd'
gdb
run thttpd on gdb.

wget
lnxsrv.seas.ucla.edu:
crash server

=============

to exploit this vulnerability, I would embed machine code in the form of
strings (convert hex code values to raw character values) as a part of my
input string and overwrite the return address of the handle_read function to
point to my code and run it.

gcc -m32 -c -S -o thttpd-nostackprot.s -fno-stack-protector -I . -I ../ thttpd.c
gcc -m32 -c -S -o thttpd-stackprot.s -fstack-protector -I . -I ../ thttpd.c
generate assembly code for sthttpd with stack protector and no stack protector

diff thttpd-stackprot.s thttpd-nostackprot.s  | less
differences between stackprot and nostackprot:

generally, stackprot was more complicated than nostackprot as it takes extra
commands in order to check for a canary and otherwise ensure that the stack
has not been corrupted.


ps aux | grep 'thttpd'
valgrind ./thttpd -p 12319
killall thttpd

gcc -m32 -c -S -o thttpd-sanitize.s -fsanitize=address -fstack-protector -I
. -I ../ thttpd.c
diff thttpd-stackprot.s thttpd-sanitize.s  | less
generate assembly code for sanitized server and diff.

generally, the sanitized code was more complex as to sanitize addresses, the
removal of relative addressing and calling __asan_report_load4 made this code
more complex.
